roomname.explanation: (Many of the rooms in the Lab stage have science themed names.)

roomname.translation: Cap per avall i cap per amunt
roomname.explanation: Flip as in gravity flip, but also the expression in english, as in, keep your cool
The room below this one is Please Forgive Me. There is also a secret path to the right which leads to the rooms 'Anomaly' and 'Purest Unobtainium'.
The room above this one is I'm Sorry
This is a type of fish with lots of thorny spikes on its back
Literally just 'Keep Going', through the room
Just describes how the room looks. 'Shuffled' as in offset.

roomname.translation: Els nens d’aquesta edat són de goma
roomname.explanation: An old saying for when e.g. a small child falls out of a tree. A trampoline joke in this case.
This room resembles a Foosball table - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Table_football
There is a teleporter in this room. The Philadelphia Experiment is the name of 80's film about teleportation.
The first room in the Lab zone. In the next room, you immediately come into contact with a gravity line, and flip back up.
The second room in the lab zone. Don't worry, it's perfectly safe.

roomname.english: Young Man, It's Worth the Challenge
roomname.translation: Xiquets, el desafiament paga la pena
roomname.explanation: Not a reference to anything in particular - Bennett explains that this is just something that his high school chemistry teacher used to say to students. He thinks the teacher was probably misquoting George Bernard Shaw, who said 'Life is not meant to be easy, my child - but take courage: it can be delightful.'.
(Many of the rooms in the Lab stage have science themed names.)
A wide section connecting to a narrower section - merge as in traffic
This room resembles a guitar chord
The crewmate Victoria is found here. Victoria is always sad! She's feeling blue.

roomname.english: Brought to you by the letter G
roomname.explanation: Reference to Seseme Street - also, this room resembles the letter G
Two people having a polite argument could be described as having a Thorny Exchange of words.
This room resembles a Square Root symbol.
This is a line from an American TV show intro about a Dolphin - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=azEOeTX1LqM
Another science themed room name, this one has two gravity lines that you bounce between.
'The living end' is an idiom meaning 'the most extreme form of something', here it's an extreme dead end, i.e. a cul-de-sac
The player falls through this room without having time to stop - AAAAAA suggests a scream in English. Also, it's six As, like the title.
This room can only be passed through in one direction. It resembles the electrical component.
When you use a photocopier, it produces a distinctive smell (from the Ozone produced). This room has a background pattern that suggests a teleportation has recently happened here.
Reference to the film The Matrix, where Morpheus jumps from the top of a Skyscaper - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ef_agVIvh0A
The room below Free Your Mind. Reference to the film Thelma and Louise, which ends with Thelma and Louise driving off a cliff, sorry, spoilers
'Hitting the Apex' is the term used by race drivers for the optimal path around a corner

roomname.translation: Dos són companyia, tres són multitud
roomname.explanation: From the expression Two's Company, Three's a Crowd. This room has two challenges - the first has two gaps to cross, the second has three.
This room has some spikes on a gravity line. The name is a reference to the device that police might use to blow out the tyres of a speeding car.
As in, a strange result in science. This room has lots of different colours, unlike other rooms in this stage.
Superman is described as being able to leap tall buildings in a single bound.
If you miss the gap in 'In a Single Bound' above, you will end up back in this room - hence, your trajectory was off!
Topsy Turvy is Australian slang for upside down
Unobtainium is a jokey made up term from science fiction for an impossible substance - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unobtainium
A Barani is a technical term for doing a flip on a trampoline
Named after the 80s song by Men Without Hats.
Many of the rooms in the Lab stage have science themed names. This one is at the beginning of a section with gravity lines above and below you, before the section begins.
This room contains a teleporter. Entanglement is an idea from quantum mechanics.
Just below the highest point in the level.
This room has an exit that sort of suggests an Exhaust Pipe in a car.
You see this Trinket just out of reach as you fall through the room.
Many of the rooms in the Lab stage have science themed names - this one is just named after a formula relating to flight.
There is a pattern in the background of this room that indicates that a teleporter has sent someone to this room
This room is a single vertically scrolling stage, about 20 rooms high. The name is from the Tarot card.
This is the room that you find the red crewmate in. (Seeing Red is an expression in English about being filled with rage, but that doesn't really apply here)
There is a teleporter in this Room. Energize is what they say on Star Trek when they use the teleporters.
Australia is sometimes called The Land Down Under because of its position on a globe. You complete this room by going down and under some moving platforms
This room appears trivial at first, but is connected to a difficult trinket challenge
An 'Apport' is a kind of paranormal teleportation. Building Apport is a pun on the concept of 'building rapport' (except that to 'apport' is to teleport).
To 'Turn that Frown Upside Down' is an expression in English, like 'cheer up', basically means to stop being unhappy
Shenanigan as in a prank, or practical joke. This room is connected to the 'Prize for the Reckless' puzzle, and like the room 'A Deception', it appears trivial unless you know the secret
This room contains a trinket that can only be collected by doing something difficult
This is the first room you encounter that has conveyor belts in it
Can only be travelled through in one direction

roomname.translation: Penetrant allà on no ha estat mai ningú
roomname.explanation: Star Trek reference, this rooms is near the entrance to the space station level
Like a filter from an air conditioning vent
Contains a single, fast moving enemy that moves up and down.
Gantry and Dolly are the names for types of cranes that move crates around. This room has two different types of platforms.
Contains a number of enemies with briefcases and the word -YES- for a head. An expression for people who work at large companies and agree a lot with their bosses
Expression meaning to take a moment and think about what you're doing. In this room, a small puzzle where you need to use the underside of a moving platform to progress.
A V Stitch is a type of crochet stitch.
As in swimming upstream or downstream, with or against a current in a river

roomname.translation: El camí més elevat és el més baix
roomname.explanation: This room has two paths - a high path and a low path. The 'low' path leads to a trinket, so the roomname is a sort of clue about which way to go.

Room is in the shape of a big letter V. The roomname suggests the common american cheerleading chant - e.g. Give me an L! Give me an O! Give me a C! Give me an A! Give me an L! Give me an I! Give me an S! Give me an A! Give me a T! Give me an I! Give me an O! Give me an N! What does it spell? LOCALISATION!
The entrance to the Space Station 2 level - the outer hull of a space station.
References a song by Kermit from the Muppets. This room is where you find the green crewmate.
An early room, name is just meant to suggest something sciency. Room contains long, wave like enemies.
This room contains some communication equipment, like a radio.

roomname.translation: Et donem la benvinguda a bord
roomname.explanation: The first room in the game
Room contains a couple of pits with soldier-like enemies in them. Loosely references the 1983 videogame Hunchback.
Room contains a large Bus. 'Bus'ted as in 'Caught'.
This room has a teleporter, which is normally found at the end of a level. However this room is midway through the stage.
This room has clouds that rise from the bottom of the screen to the top, which the player is faster than, implying that the player is lighter than air.
This room has a factory and pollution clouds in it. Apparently this phrase was once used by industrialists to advocate for not worrying too much about pollution.
This room contains a speaker that emits the word 'LIES' over and over. A cuckoo's call decieves other birds!
A conveyor belt in this room pushes against you as you try to move, so you slide backwards.
There are two paths you can pick between here

roomname.translation: Els verds no la saben invertir
roomname.explanation: You have a green crewmate with you in this room! A reference to the 90's film 'White Guy's Can't Jump'.
literally as in, this is how the mechanic of this stage works - also an expression as in 'this is the way things are'

roomname.english: That's Why I Have To Kill You
roomname.translation: I per això t’haig de matar
roomname.explanation: The follows the room named 'I love you'. 'I love you, that's why I have to kill you' is kind of a slasher horror trope.
An early room, looks a bit like an air filter

roomname.translation: No és cap secret per a ningú
roomname.explanation: A reference to the infamous Zelda quote 'It's a secret to everybody'. This room contains the first trinket.
Conundrum as in puzzle, riddle, problem to be solved
Contains a challenge that you need to react very quickly to. You might say 'Boo, think fast' if you threw something at someone, expecting them to catch it.
Early corridor room containing no challenges. Sensible as in the opposite of Foolish - you might call someone sensible in english if they are excessively cautious.
Named after the Tarot Card, reversed as in Upside Down. The room contains a stationary enemy which resembles a Wheel of Fortune. The name is supposed to suggest a kind of out-of-place quality.
A peaceful green room.
A reference to the 8-bit game Manic Miner.

A 'Clarion Call' is an idiom used when somebody makes a case for a course of action, for example in a politician's speech, or a call to battle. It sometimes has an association with dishonesty - in this room, the words 'LIES' appear over and over.
As in the Gordian Knot from greek history. A complicated room that can be passed through twice.
This room comes right after a choice between two paths. It's a quote from an Indiana Jones film.
Room contains a teleporter. A 'Murdering Twinmaker' is, uh, one way teleportation might work...
Room is a spiral, cut down the middle
This is a Matrix reference that hasn't aged well, lol
The enemies in this room are Stop Signs
To take a leap of faith means to do something without knowing how it's going to turn out.
As in being alone, or in this case, lost by yourself
Technically references the name of a C64 game, but that doesn't matter much
Like a factory exhaust chute for disposing of rubbish
A difficult room that you might die in a lot

The room is above 'Swoop', and is a copy of the room rotated 180 degrees! The room name 'doomS' is the word 'Swoop' rotated 180 degrees. When localising this room, don't worry too much about trying to keep the meaning of the words Dooms and Swoop, because they're not that important - instead, focus on picking words that have this 180 degree flip quality!
See the note for room (15,9), doomS.
This refers to a famous philosophical argument about artifical intelligence - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_room.

roomname.translation: No fas res més que tornar aquí
roomname.explanation: You can pass through this room up to three times, depending on which route you take through the level.
A conveyor belt will take you through this room without you needing to press any buttons, hench the bypass. The phrase Hyperspace Bypass is a reference to Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy.
The room contains a couple of heart shaped enemies
This room can be approached in two different equivilent ways, whichever way you like it. 'As you like it' is the name of a Shakespeare play.
Probably named after the 80s film Short Circuit. Also works because you'll hit a dead end if you keep walking forwards.
A maze like room. Refers to the section from the 1976 text game Colossal Cave Adventure - you are in a maze of twisty little passages, all alike
Contains lots of dissolving platforms.
A very obscure reference to the C64 game Dizzy
This room contains a section of wall in the shape of a parabolic arch.
This is a green room that resembles a dollar sign shape

The room below this contains enemies in the shape of the word 'Lies'. So there's a double meaning here - as in, a question, 'what is below this room', and that the word LIES is literally beneath this room.
This rooms is below the room named 'What lies Beneath?', and answers the question: Spikes do!

roomname.translation: Ha, ha, ha! La veritat és que no!
roomname.explanation: This is a difficult room that follows one called 'Plain Sailing from here on'. It's taunting the player.

roomname.translation: A partir d’aquí tot seran flors i violes
roomname.explanation: This room is at the end of a long section, and promises 'Plain Sailing' afterwards, as in, no further challenges. This is a lie

roomname.english: As we go up, we go down
roomname.translation: El sostre és el terra i al revés
roomname.explanation: Named after the 1995 song by Guided by Voices
This room is a maze which has no entrance, due to the nature of the warping mechanic.
I think this is an Ultima 7 reference? A literal translation is fine here

Contains a trinket that you get by navigating around the edge of the screen. The use of the word EDGE is deliberate, refering to the trademark of a notoriously litigious individual who sued an indie developer around the time VVVVVV was made

roomname.english: Brass Sent Us Under The Top
roomname.explanation: The enemies in this room look like little army guys

This room has lots of checkpoints in it. It's beside the game's most difficult challenge, the Veni, Vidi, Vici section. The checkpoints don't really do anything, but they're a warning of the challenge ahead.
A two part room name. From the expression 'If you fall down, just pick yourself up'.
A two part room name. From the expression 'If you fall down, just pick yourself up'.

roomname.translation: El receptor que s’ho empassa tot
roomname.explanation: Just some nice wordplay. Chipper means 'Jolly' or 'Happy'.
Literal, this is the first room in the stage which is fairly difficult
Apparently a scientist named John Wheeler coined the phrase 'Wormhole'! I just found that out. Anyway, this room has a teleporter in it.
Contains enemies that move strangly and resemble enemies from ZZT, an old game by Tim Sweeney
Refers to what train announcers say on the London Underground when you leave the train - mind the gap between the train and the station platform
The name of a 60's science fiction book. There is a teleporter in this room.

roomname.english: Getting Here is Half the Fun
roomname.translation: Arribar aquí és sols la meitat del camí
roomname.explanation: The top of the Veni Vidi Vici sequence. When you get to the top, you have to go all the way back down - hence, this room is the halfway point of the challenge.
Part of the Veni Vidi Vici sequence. Taunting the player.

Part of the Veni Vidi Vici sequence. Taunting the player - the 'easy mode' refers to the second passageway on the right side that is easier to take when going back through this room on the way down, but that passageway leads to death.
The rooms Veni, Vidi, Vici! appear in sequence. Famous latin phrase attributed to Julius Caesar meaning I came, I saw, I conquered. The hardest challenge in the game.
The rooms Veni, Vidi, Vici! appear in sequence. Famous latin phrase attributed to Julius Caesar meaning I came, I saw, I conquered. The hardest challenge in the game.
The rooms Veni, Vidi, Vici! appear in sequence. Famous latin phrase attributed to Julius Caesar meaning I came, I saw, I conquered. The hardest challenge in the game.

roomname.translation: Les coses es fan de la manera difícil
roomname.explanation: The starting room from the Veni, Vidi, Vici! challenge.
The Batcave, as in Batman's hideout.
Just meant as in literally Ascending and Descending, going up and down. There is a room later in the game called Upstairs, Downstairs, which is a callback to this.

roomname.translation: El genet de l’ona de xoc
roomname.explanation: Named after a 70's Science Fiction novel
Flip is used here in the sense 'Flip out', as in, to lose your temper
Refers to 1950 Silverstone Grand Prix (The final stage has room names that suggest old black and white TV shows.)

roomname.translation: Repara la V sense ajuda externa
roomname.explanation: DIY TV repair - this room has a television you can interact with, which changes the theme from black and white to colour
This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.
The first room after the black and white section. Doesn't refer to any TV show.
This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.
Named after The Goon Show (The final stage has room names that suggest old black and white TV shows.)

Named after the 70s TV show - but also, refers to the earlier room Ascending and Descending, which this room is an updated version of. (Second part of the final stage has references to Colour TV shows)

roomname.translation: No vulguis avançar tan de sobte!
roomname.explanation: This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.
Named after the Hitchcock film (The final stage has room names that suggest old black and white TV shows.)

Named after the 70s TV show - name also suggests a connection to the earlier room Backsliders, which this room is an updated version of (Second part of the final stage has references to Colour TV shows)
This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.

roomname.translation: Dos són companyia, tres són fantasia
roomname.explanation: Named after the 70s sitcom - but also, suggests a connection to the earlier room Two's Company, which this room is an updated version of (Second part of the final stage has references to Colour TV shows)

roomname.english: Must I Do Everything For You?
roomname.translation: Què vols, que t’ho faci tot jo?
roomname.explanation: This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.
Opening room of the final level.

roomname.translation: Ara no te’n vagis gaire lluny...
roomname.explanation: This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.
Named after the cat from the 70s film Bedknobs and Broomsticks. Not sure why!
I don't think V-hold is a real thing, it's supposed to just suggest 'Do not adjust your TV settings'. (The final stage has room names that suggest old black and white TV shows.)
In this room, if you go too quickly, your crewmate will walk into spikes.
Bennett just thought this room looked 'intestinal'. Villi as in part of the intestinal system. Also refers to the 80s band The Village People.

roomname.translation: El servei es recuperarà ben aviat
roomname.explanation: This is something you might hear on a TV station if they had lost reception. (The final stage has room names that suggest old black and white TV shows. A really, really good way to translate this level would be to use the names of black and white TV shows that are well known in your language, rather than trying to keep the exact meaning of the TV shows used here.)
This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.

A panic room is a safe room that you can hide in during an emergency, but I don't think that was Bennett's intention with this name. This room suddenly starts scrolling as soon as you enter, causing a panic.
As in folded paper - this room is mirrored around the center point.
This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.
Refers to the 3 Stooges (The final stage has room names that suggest old black and white TV shows.)

roomname.translation: Vinil de la Copa del Món de 1954
roomname.explanation: Refers to the World Cup Final (The final stage has room names that suggest old black and white TV shows.)
This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.
One of the last challenges in the game.

roomname.translation: Vés amb compte amb el cap
roomname.explanation: This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.

roomname.translation: La gota que fa vessar el got
roomname.explanation: One more little challenge, just after the room called The Final Challenge
This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.
Refers to Wii Sports, the Nintendo Wii launch title. 'Whee' as in what a child might say while going down a slide (this room has a long drop in it)
Whizz is Australian slang for doing something quickly, I think
A special arcade section where you have to survive for 60 seconds. Bennett named this one so as to suggest a funfair ride (though not any one in particular).
Another name inspired by funfairs.
Another name inspired by funfairs.
This room has platforms in a W shape.
This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.
Final sequence of rooms that spell out V-V-V-V-V-V, 6/6
Final sequence of rooms that spell out V-V-V-V-V-V, 5/6
Final sequence of rooms that spell out V-V-V-V-V-V, 4/6
Final sequence of rooms that spell out V-V-V-V-V-V, 3/6
Final sequence of rooms that spell out V-V-V-V-V-V, 2/6
Final sequence of rooms that spell out V-V-V-V-V-V, 1/6
This entire intermission section has a tone of a strict schoolteacher leading a small child.
